div1.p: Returned from a trip to Aztec, N.M. yesterday and was Thrilled to find your letter waiting for me at the P.O. tyhis morning.

The occasion for the trip was a visit to an old aunt of Faye's who lives there. She is 85 yrs old ,ve5ry bright and alert; a wonderful old pioneer type lady. Went to Loveland, Colo., where We picked up my Faye's brother and wife and older sister; thence3# via Glenwood Springs to Grand Ju nction; to Montrose; Uray to Silverton, over the "Million Dollar Highway", on to Aztec N.M. via Durange, Colo to Aztec. Returned via Del Norte and Salida ,across South pPark;through Fair PLlay, to Denver. Had a delightful trip.The mountains were beautiful in theretheir autumn glory. I was especially thrillled by the trip over the "mMillion Dollar Highway" through the "aAlps of America" for, about 35 yrs. ago ,as Asst. Engineer for the U.S. BureaBureau of Public Roads, I heplped stake one of othe most difficult stretches. It was across an almost barren,very sharply pitched, granite face on Red Mountain, with a 1200 ft canyon just below. I had to set up the transit in any crevasse I could find and the boys with the rods worked on ropes attached to iron pins set in the rock above.

Yes- John there does seem to be some sort of phsycicpsychic connection between us. I have wondered some times; we were both close to our mothers,and they were very, very, close. Perhaps, in some way, this gives us a sort of physycicpsychic relationship. Any way, I am very happy about it.

I did know that you were connected in some way with the University at Columbia, but did not know your address. Am surely glad that thigngs have worked out so well for you and yours. I may be confused in my recolectionsrecollections, but I believe that Sigurd was just leaving you the day we visited you at Branson. If my memoriy is correct, he had been trained
24 "2"
in music, and wast then setting out on a more commercial task, perhaps sell ing musical instruments. I just sensed that you forlks were troubled about him. If this is correct, it is surely grand that he "found himself" in mechanical lines instead of Art. One time years ago, you told me that "Just as the plant lived to produce the flower and then died,so the generatation lived to produce great artists". Althougyh I said nothing, I could never quite accept that philosiphyphilosophy and wondered if,in the Great Plan, the seed was not the culmination, rather than the Flower.

Does Mona still work at her sculpturing ? When we were there, she was nearing completion of a bust of some great educator, head of the " CollageCollege of the Ozarks,? of Of the Hills ?", Does it still exist?

I know that you are enjoying your hobby of horses and the awssociation with other horse lovers .(Did you ever make your "trek" over the great Salt Flats,? I have been across them several times by car and each time I thought of you and wondered.) I say I know that you are enjoying your hobby for ours is Irish Setter dogs . We still have "Boyne," 11 yrs. old, registered as "Atomic InasionInvasion",sired by Finefield Invasion, by Klieglight of Arrogan,— who was the greastestgreatest eIrish Setter champion the U.S. ever produced. We showed him for a couple of seasons, around the Mid-West Circuit ,as apupya puppy novice,and at 2yrs. He was just "coming into his own" when , with us,on a trailer trip, in 1949,he was hit by an express train on a beach at Pensacola,Fla.. His leg was broken in ther right thigh and the pelvic arch broken. After a battle ,we pulled him through, but his gait was spoiled for the ring. We only used him for breeding once , to provide for his soccessorsuccessor "Red Feather Flash" now 5yrs.old. Flash, thougyh a disappoinnttmemtdisappointment in certain show qualities,(too many of the weaknesses of htthe lmother, Lady of Lockwookd, is a wonderfully intelligent dog. Though we have never been blessed with children, we have had the wonderful,unselfish inspiring love, yes worship, of some great dogs. (Some day IwillI will tell you more about them.0) I have just one advantage over you in my hobby;just a littllittle closer association . Am not ashamed to say that two of my dogs have died in my arms and someday,before too long Boyne will.

We stopped in Denver on our way back and for a periodical check on my eyes. I have cataracts on both eyes . Slight on the left.----- "Not enougyh deteriationdeterioration to warrant change of glasses and cataracts not rp ripe for an operation. Come back after the first of the year." Thankful they are not so bad but what I can still drive a car and can read fairly well. I am going ahead with preparatniions for fall wildfowl hunting,though a poor "shooting eye" is somehwat of a handicap.
I b ought "When the Tree FlowersFlowered" in Denver when it first came out and am re-reading it again now.
I knew you would have a hard time deciphering the scrawl I sent to youo ------
My histeryhistory "friend" at Kansas Staate, is my brother Floyd's oldest son. I am sending the letters on to him.
